author: chrissorem
content: This made me think of a production technique Ive stumbled on.  We all have our go to instincts that can lead to a similar feeling across a  record.  Generally there is a dominant instrument that the song was written on such as guitar or piano maybe a synth.  Take a filled out productions and mute all the main ingredients and leave the additive colors, only the sprinkles on top. And start rebuilding the production around that. It can take you to an entirely different  universe and provide contrast in the arch of the record

author: BatMeckley
content: I would say it’s not one or the other. Like, I might do some big timing moves first, just to have the vocal 80% of the way there. I’m talking actually nudging things around, not stretching. Then I’ll consolidate and drop into Melodyne. In Melodyne I’ll turn the whole thing and also really pay attention to the timing. At this stage it’s a lot more stretching and/or compressing notes, or more importantly PARTS of words. Like I’ll separate the consonant, and time compress that and bring up the volume so ccchhhhhhhhair becomes CHaaaaiiirrrr. (If that makes any sense). Then back into ProTools. Double check for any weirdness, comp back in the untuned bits you can get away with if you want. Then I’ll do a final cleaning up of group Esses, do my little what I call Swedish time stretching technique, REALLY pocket and polish the vocals. Then I send it off to the label who needed it yesterday but somehow don’t get back to me for 6 months.

author: BatMeckley
content: I mostly fuck with retune speed; adjusting it slows down how hard the tune snaps to the note and it can basically reduce the “severity” of the effect. Classic mode is because when they went from 5 to 7 we all threw a fit because they fucked heavily with the “sound” of the plug in. In an effort to increase transparency they actually messed with the high end artifacts we actually dug, and were using the plugin for (on a lot of the Luke records I worked on we were using melodyne for tune and AutoTune for tone). I clearly remember sitting on the phone with Antares brass for HOURS while they tried to convince us the new version was “better” and me having to explain to them that it wasn’t and we were now traveling with rigs that had the old version because the new version just didn’t have the sound we needed. They compromised by introducing “classic” mode which was their attempt to get the sound of v5 back.

author: austenballard
content:
**RESULTS**

Null testing revealed that the tuned audio did not completely cancel out between any of the three files, even when audio was time-aligned and gain-matched. Audible signal at approx. -36 dBFS was present during playback.

Furthermore, each instance of Melodyne did not detect the audio identically. The plugin version detected Tone #1 at +48 ct, while ARA and Standalone detected it at + 50 ct. No difference was noted in the detected pitch center of Tone #2 between the three instances.

**DISCUSSION**

Testing showed Beckley, et al. (2023) to be correct in asserting that Melodyne does not behave identically between its plugin, ARA and standalone versions. Differences do not appear limited to the tuning algorithm, but indeed the detection algorithm as well. The relative subjective quality of tuning results between these versions cannot, however, be determined by the present test. Further testing and qualitative evaluation may be needed to add to the literature and determine the most preferable version of Melodyne to use for tuning purposes.

author: BatMeckley
content:
<deep breath>
So, grasshopper, everything matters, and nothing matters. It depends on where you are and where you’re going, and most importantly actually knowing where you’re going.

I view the difference in shitty gear vs good gear as compound interest. A vintech one on one might sound basically like a vintage neve. ALMOST indistinguishable. But if you’re using it on all 149 of the tracks you’re compiling into a pop song, the end result is going to be 149 times more noticeable. The second floor of the leaning tower of Pisa looks pretty spot on but the people on the 15th floor are freaking out. 

That said, I could record a garbage singer through my 251 and my chain, and if I didn’t know what to do with it, it would still be garbage. The flip side is we actually demoed different mics and different chains on Paris Hilton. There was a right answer. And she’s not gonna win any singing contests, but at the end of the day the cumulative effect of all the decisions we made led to tracks that are still being played in clubs to make people dance over a decade later.

Details matter in not just what the audience hears eventually, but what the artist hears initially, giving them the confidence and headspace to sprinkle in their extra few (sometime more than a few) percentage points of vibe that the audience attaches too later. Fix it in the mix is an abused concept because it doesn’t take in to account the affect of shitty sound or feel on the performance. You think 1 mic doesn’t matter? I’ve heard people sing noticeably more in tune and in time when switching from DAW monitoring to direct monitoring. It ALL matters.

But if you don’t understand songs, melody, rhythm, and how these things interact to move people? None of it matters.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Ok. One last example (since I've already gone this far). Miles Davis. 

Miles had the technical chops. He had fathomless musical depth. He could write every single note of a big band chart if he wanted to, but he (with a few early exceptions) never did this.

His recipe for music making was this: 

A) Start with a great song (chords and melody)
B) Curate a team of players with their own strong musical identities 
C) Bring them together and let them interpret the song
D) Direct them on feel and how to listen to and respond to each other

That's it. Miles' music was never about big arranging moments, or written-out parts. He started with great raw material, great players, and great prompting and then he let them roam free and play.

So that's one more way to approach it. 

There are two things that I keep coming back to in all of this: A great song and a vision. If you have those you can set your players free to surprise and astound you.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Granted, her examples are *very* specific to orchestra and not directly applicable to pop records, but the underlying principles here include:

**1) **Think of instrument combinations as a single composite voice.

One instrument can function as the "sustain" portion of the sound and a second instrument gives the "attack". Together they create a single melodic voice.

**2) **How do the instruments stack on each other? Do they clash? Cellos doubling a bass an octave up extend it's timbre into a higher register to make it read better. It's not so different from adding fuzz to an 808 so that it has more presence.

**3) **Which instrument will cut through the music?

---

A few concepts that I'll add:

**4) **Instruments in the foreground vs. the background. Know which part is the lead (focal point) at any given point in the record and then pare down the presence of the rest and push it into the back of the sound stage.

**5)** (Piggybacking off of Felix's excellent post) What is the simplest way to achieve the desired effect? Reduce. Reduce. Reduce.

Cut instruments and parts ruthlessly and approach it with a minimalist's eye. Like writing a haiku: How few elements can you use to create an impression? Maybe a guitar part is carrying 90% of the groove and the drums only need to be a kick and a snare. Or maybe the guitar is covering the backbeat too, and you don't even need a snare!

Constantly ask yourself "What is the most important sensation in the record?" and then focus it by cutting out everything that gets in the way.

**6)** Hocketing. Pass the melody off between different instruments at different points in the song. Play it in different registers. Combine voices occasionally for special effect.

**7)** Tonal contrast. Dark instruments plus bright instruments. Distorted and clean together. Near vs. distant.

Elements that sound same-y will gel together and elements that contrast tonally will pop.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
To go further on what @Maxim said: when you stack a bunch of vocals that are all hard tuned, they're gonna phase cancel. I often detune L/R doubles of a lead by a few 10ths of a cycle (like take the left channel to 439.4hz and the right channel to 440.6hz in auto tune) to help separate them.

This is actually what a "chorus" effect is meant to do. When you actually get a bunch of great singers together to sing the same thing, their different timbres and slightly different pitches will add up to a very rich sound you can't get from stacking one tuned voice. That's what the effect called "chorus" is essentially trying to mimic with slight detune and delay.

Not sure if this is a topic we've covered much but I know @BatMeckley and @Slow Hand have thoughts

author: BatMeckley
content:
Essentially this. If you get vocals too tight they’ll start to phase cancel (and or feel mono if they’re panned.) I was just talking about this a day or two ago in the discord except in that case using melodyne. 

The technique that matt is saying is essentially a micro shift plugin or an h949. The one thing I’d say about that is you’re using a technique to fix a problem halfway that you’ve made for yourself in the first place. Remember WHY you’re stacking vocals. You want some thickness or some stereo spread. Don’t tune and time them as aggressively from the jump and you’ll be good

author: Slow Hand
content:
At the risk of stating the obvious, transitions can also be telegraphed through the instrumental writing too. Whether it's a drum fill, or a chord voicing that walks up/down into the next section, or tension in the melodic voices, or shortening the notes lengths (staccato, staccatissimo).

There's also idiomatic noises from the instruments. Guitars have string scrapes, headstock rakes, that cool chattering thing from tapping near the bridge with the edge of your pick. Pianos have big glisses, horns can squeal, bowed strings can sweep a fast legato scale up into the downbeat or do a large gliss.

Then there's foley. I get a *lot* of mileage from sound libraries made for film audio. Foley artists are some creative people and you can go far layering their sounds into instruments at the transitions.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I think these things are cumulative… so…
Vintech was able to sell a ton of units because on the NAMM floor their pre was indistinguishable from a 1073 costing 4 times as much. But, if you took one home and used it as your one pre across 100 tracks of your masterpiece, even your parents are going to hear the difference between it and a vintage neve. That small 5% difference really added up at the end. I’m sure after floor two of the leaning tower of Pisa the engineers we’re like “lookin good boss! 👍🏼 “ and it wasn’t til they compounded their error that people started to panic.
If you’re making tracks 95% in the box with samples and soft synths and then just drop a featured rapper on top of it, it’s probably not going to matter if you use a Scarlett or an Apollo or an Apogee. But if you’re a professional mixer constantly printing stuff 100x a session through outboard gear you’re going to notice a difference I can guarantee you. Or if you’re doing a Low record where there’s only three elements and one of them is the most gifted voice of a generation, the gear is going to matter a lot more than if you’re squeezing a TikTok star into 37 plugins and then into a 150 track mix.

So at the end of the day, much like producing, songwriting or pretty much everything else in life, it’s that old prayer of strength to change the things you can, the grace to accept the things you can’t, and the most important bit that everyone seems to skip over, THE WISDOM TO KNOW THE DIFFERENCE. 

Do what works for you, and clearly, I sweat the details enough to notice that the algorithms are different, or Cians dangerous was down a half a db on one side, but also, when to actually use that information to actually make the actual point. Otherwise you end up being a photographer that does nothing but collect backs and lenses but never actually takes a photo.

author: austenballard
content:
See, that's just it... I might not have come far yet, but the road I've been down was riddled with things falling apart on account of overlooked details and compound deficiencies. I'm very sensitive to that aspect of this whole thing.

And on wisdom? I don't have the wisdom to know the difference most of the time. I sweat details like crazy. I hyperfixate. I'm looking to you (you specifically and y'all who've been doing this a while broadly) for that wisdom, because it's in critically short supply elsewhere. But don't think for a second that it's taken for granted. I know it's been hard won over a long time, and it's a privilege to be able to read your takes and pick your brain on things as seemingly mundane as what SR to run Melodyne at. 

And maybe after a lot more sticking around here, and a lot more reps of *everything*, maybe I'll achieve a modicum of wisdom. In the mean time, it doesn't hurt every once in a while to have someone who knows better remind you not to lose the forest for the trees.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
Wanted to share some thoughts spurred on by a recent experience on here. So a local artist has hired me to produce two of her songs. Vibe is singer-songwriter, soul, RnB.

We tracked drums, bass, and keys live in the studio OD'd to scratch tracks we cooked up together. The scratch tracks / demos were just guitar vocal and we were really relying on the players to fill out the arrangements, but we knew more would be added down the line.

All the players were incredible. Could singe your eyebrows off with technical prowess and shredtastic chops. Tracks turned out great, still working on the arrangement, but..

This project has got me thinking more about the importance of how you present a song to session musicians and the 'space' you ask them to fill in a production. As well as the changing dynamics project to project affected by a revolving cast of participants, more fleshed out demos, etc... I find this a really interesting topic. Curious if anyone in the group has any unique experiences or insights whether as a producer or a musician.

I've found that the more I flesh out demos with the artist beforehand the more bound and limited the session players we bring in are based off our decisions. This can make ODs more efficient, add a clearer direction, but can also remove the opportunity for the player to really add something special. Sometimes I don't want to be too suggestive b/c I want the players to have more of a blank canvas to work with.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I mean, at the risk of over simplifying what it is we do, just listen. If you’re getting too much consonant already, I certainly don’t recommend over hyping the consonant any further. 😂

It’s like “how do you know when to use the maag eq to boost the high?” Answer: when it doesn’t sound bright enough. 

The other night I was at a table full of very very very good producers and mixers, and a discussion on the merits of Serban broke out, and there was talk about compression and limiting and making something sound like it comes out of fm radio already and how that effects the human nervous system and… and i was just like, I dunno man, I always thought that we went to Serban because he made sure you could understand the words. Lol. I think a lot of times as producers we can very quickly lose the forrest from the trees and fixate on the upper harmonic character of spectre at a certain oversampling level and it’s like yeah, but man, your song doesn’t have a bridge and the melody is forgettable. It’s like the people that put $10,000 spinner rims on a $700 ‘88 Nissan Maxima. Worry about the color and consistency of the icing once you’ve baked a kickass cake, not before. 

(I also know you’re not the target market for this advice cause you’re already killing it, this is more for the people reading through the discord.)

author: LAPhill
content:
Okay @Nomograph Mastering , so I think the analogy is a little off. Music is a conversation, but it's a conversation between performers. At it's best, the performance is authentic, transcendent, and speaks to our souls in a way that real-world conversation with words can't do. But it's heightened, exaggerated, hyper-focused. If the song is written ahead of time, it's more akin to actors interpreting a script. The words are written, the notes are there. Unless we're talking about jazz improvisation, which is the closest we come to real world conversation, but even then, it's translated and performed. As much as Miles was saying what he wanted to say, he was saying it that way so that an audience would hear it, it wasn't a private conversation.

Now, if you get incredible actors on a stage or in front of a camera, you can let them do their thing with minimal trickery, minimal edits, and it will move you to tears. The respond to each other and elevate the piece beyond what feels possible. Watch that same play as a community theater-level performance and feel nothing. The reality is that a lot of the artists that are coming through aren't Sidney Poitier. They're just not that good at making their music feel effortless. Not every play works as a film, and vice versa. Not every track benefits from having a band in a room. 

Confusing the genesis of songwriting (one person crafting both sides of a conversation) with the act of expressing that work (one person performing every part, a la Tom Hanks' motion capture of every character in The Polar Express). I know that ultimately you and I agree on the benefits of humans recording together, but the analogy feels too blurry to me.

author: LAPhill
content: Not always that relevant in modern music, but our brains mostly hear the relationship between melody and bassline, with inner voices a distant second. So thoughtful voice leading and intervalic relationships between the bass and melody can negate the need for much other harmonic information.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yes. *Supermassive* gets regular usage over here. Sean should charge for that plugin because it's so good.

It's a delay plugin that specializes in super-long and evolving echoes with lots of modulation. Sean has described the different algorithms as "too exotic" for his other plugins so he bundled them all together as *Supermassive*.

It certainly excels in that role, and also doubles as a good lush reverb when you turn up the diffusion knob.

Funnily, I almost never use it for long echoes. As it turns out, it's really good at creating super-tight and roomy sounds. Just dial the delay time to < 15 ms and turn up the feedback and suddenly you have a very lush and chorus-y "room" sound. Kind of like a Quantec or something from a Jimmy Edgar record.

author: peterlabberton
content: Under 40 hz? If we’re taking *that* low, in my experience usually kicks benefit from sitting just slightly above that range, especially in rock—somewhere around 50-60hz. Usually they sound punchier and less flabby with just a touch of the super low lows rolled off. Basses can move around a bit more, obviously, but I also find that usually even if you have a fundamental around or below 40 hz, the first harmonic an octave above is usually what you’re actually interested in. Also it’s very song/arrangement/tempo (!) dependent! A slower tempo or less busy kick pattern or song arrangement will let you get away with loads more super sub stuff. Faster patterns will just sound like flabby mush with tons of sub.

author: gatewoodsensei
content:
Absolutely. I went from FL to Ableton and Logic (before Ableton got comping), then played with Bitwig, Cubase and a bunch of other DAWs and S1 by far is the most comprehensive. It’s like the developers sat back and said “I see what they’re doing but what if we made it more streamlined.” Not to turn this into the daw thread, but I’ll give you an example. In order to create a reverse reverb effect, I’d have to cut the part that i want to reverse, duplicate the track in a way that only copies the plugins, drag the cut audio down to the new track, add a reverb, reverse the audio, bounce in place, reverse again, and line it up. 

In studio one, I can create a custom macro that adds all of those commands to one command in sequence and turn that one command into a button. Effectively turning what, like 8 steps, into one. And it does it in seconds.

author: austenballard
content:
Test is done. Tl;dr they don't null completely. They don't even detect the same audio the same.

**INTRODUCTION**
Beckley, et al. (2023) reported differences in tuning results between the plugin and standalone versions of Melodyne. This investigator undertook a test of Melodyne plugin, ARA and standalone versions to determine whether the resulting tuned audio would null.

**METHODS**

All testing was performed at a sample rate of 48kHz and with .wav files at a bit depth of 32 bits. Tuning was tested using two 2-second square wave tones generated with FabFilter One in Logic Pro X. Tone #1 was generated at a constant pitch of C4 +50ct. Tone #2 was generated at a pitch of C4 with the following settings: Modulation Generator (MG) Frequency set to 4.033 Hz,  MG waveform set to value 0.500, and Frequency Modulation MG set to value 0.123. Each tone was printed on a separate channel as a Bounce-in-place (bip). The two bips were then joined into a single, 6-second, mono .wav file with 2 seconds of silence between the bips. The 6-second .wav file was copied onto two new channels in Logic Pro X, and dragged out of Logic Pro onto the desktop for use in Melodyne standalone.

Audio was transferred into Melodyne: one mono channel in Logic Pro X was loaded with an instance of Melodyne non-ARA, one mono channel in Logic Pro X was loaded with an instance of Melodyne ARA, and the copy of the .wav file on the desktop was loaded into Melodyne standalone. All transfers were completed using the Melodic (Standard) algorithm. 

Transferred audio was quantized to pitch C4, offset 0 ct, Pitch Modulation 0.0%, Pitch Drift 0.0%. All other settings were left at defaults; Note Assignment mode was checked to verify that Playback Type in each case was 'Tonal'. 

Resulting audio was printed and imported into three new mono channels in Logic Pro X. Null testing was performed using the phase invert feature in Logic Pro X's stock 'Gain' plugin.

author: BatMeckley
content: I was just bringing it up to be a schmuck and mildly difficult (largely because DP’s camp was pretty difficult with us when we’re on intersecting tours forever ago)  but it does bring up an important TOTALLY UNRELATED TO YOUR SPECIFIC DANIEL POWTER situation point: we’re in the business of tiny differences making huge differences. You can get a Warm 47 for a grand or real 47 for 15 grand and they’re preeeetttyy  close. But the devil is in the details. The original Dare you to Move (I think that song has had 4 different versions now) is pretty close to the Fields version… Fields rocked up the drums a little more, and by far most importantly  had my sage input (and gear) for a more kickass guitar sound. The song went from a heavily pushed song that couldn’t quite get its footing for them to a massive multi platinum career defining hit. It can be frustrating to watch someone else turn something we got 95% of the way there into the thing that got released, but often times it’s that exact skill which makes them worth the investment from the label. Understanding that difference and learning how to bridge the gap is the whole secret to making a living in this business.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I’m KINDA kidding, we’ve gone over this a lot on here… I much prefer the standalone workflow, but there’s a ton of people that swear by it in plugin form, it just doesn’t work for me that way, and I get different sounding results partly because of workflow and partly because we’ve verified they actually sound different (different algorithms). 

Melodyne is an incredible tool, but it’s not without its quirks. The first thing is: the correction is only as good as the detection… so it’s worth a quick run through to make sure it’s mapped the vocal take properly.  Sometimes it gets a syllable or two in the wrong octave, and rarer times it’ll get it wrong a fourth or fifth off. I’m not sure the process for correcting that in the plug in off the top of my head. Once you’ve got the detection right…

The  next step is understanding how we fundamentally sing; a note tends to have a front end or consonance, the meat of the note, and then lastly the tail. You want to separate the meat of the note out, and concentrate on tuning that. Also remember that the “blob” is just an average of the tuning info in it, meaning if your note slides from C to E, melodyne will correct that blob to D. (I hope that makes sense.)

author: BatMeckley
content:
These are two different things.
If you are doing meticulous need to be unbothered nerd shit, it’s great to have someone to keep the artist entertained. 

I would lose my mind, and my intern, if they kept interrupting a creative flow to yap. 

Again, (again again again), this business is 20% understanding gear, and 80% understanding people. You have to know your artists. Often, id even argue more often than not, it’s the fuckery and the messing around that often inspires the best ideas. We tend to be very bad at being creative with a gun to our head. As a producer, I’m trying to foster that safety and relaxation, while taking a Birds Eye view of the conversation listening for anything that I can go “wait! THAT was a lyric” or a riff or whatever. That’s always worked much better than me staring at someone going “hush. Write.”

Occasionally, like the old Peter Gabriel SO story, you have to lock the artist in the room and tell them they can’t come out until they’re done. But most of the time that just gets the job done, rather than the job done well.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
I've been melodyning vocals for a ten song album past couple weeks and feel like I've leveled up my chops significantly. I'm no Beckley, but browsing whats been previously shared here and trial and error has been the mechanism of growth for me.

I kinda had the note separation tool workflow down from work in other programs. I've been experimenting with the time tool and attack speed tool as well as formant shifting to mask when the tuning becomes more audible than I'd like. That's probably where I'd pinpoint the level up for me personally. That and trying to be more conscious about not relying too much on the graphical UI. Unless it's something that really calls for hard tuning I lean towards wanting it to feel invisible / natural. Im realizing more what parts of the note actually need to be more 'on' and which can be more 'off' or just left alone. That and letting notes naturally drift to become more sharp as they tail off. If I'm too heavy handed it starts to feel lifeless to me. I'm also appreciating more the nuance of how one might approach different genres or styles with melodyne. Its humbling how powerful the program really is.

There've been a few moments with the attack speed tool that have felt like magic curing some subtleties of the performances that bug me, but I don't feel super confident that I have a grasp on that one yet. I've been working in standalone and importing a REF mix. For some reason I feel more confident dealing with esses in protools with RX or clip gain than I do melodyne idk why. Some frustrations have been flipping back and forth between tracks when tuning multiple files feels real clunky. I might be missing something about how best to do that. I wish, like with RX monitor, you could hear the vocal through your mix chain when tuning (is that possible?). Being able to rename exported files would be nice too like in RX.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I’ve been thinking about @Joel "Roomie" Berghult‘s question re: mixing as you since he asked it. I think what Rauirí says about not knowing what we’re doing while we’re doing it is really true, so I’ve just been trying to dissect my process in my brain, away from the computer.  I think it comes down to 2 things for me. 

Here are my thoughts:


1) Choosing Sounds. 

In addition to vibe & genre & emotional intent, each instrument or sample that you pick covers a certain area of the overall picture. Knowing where that part is going to go in the overall arrangement changes how much hi end or low end or wetness (etc.) you want. It also steers performances. 

2) Actually Mixing As You Go 

Once a part is recorded, do a quick adjustment so that you hear closer to a finished product. This helps you make better choices about what else needs to be added, (or not added,) and will likely inspire the next step.

author: chrissorem
content: I was in a similar situation last week, and  there were a few times where I found myself thinking, “shit this has turned for the worse, how do I steer us back to main land”. What I concluded was you have to be patient and let them try the ideas hear them out and if you feel strongly about something, tell them what you feel in a way that makes them feel like you care and explain without it becoming a speech why you aren’t feeling the idea. And try to follow it up with an idea that you think works.  In my case I  said “ we all love the foundation and we landed somewhere and that feels good. Now we have to be disciplined and be sure that anything we add is truly adding and not taking us away from our northern star.”  And if you think they have bad ideas that they are glued to, ask questions, why do you feel this part has to be here, what is it doing for the song as a whole? Ect. For an arrangement you should be able to hash that out quickly, there are only so many options

author: BatMeckley
content:
I know I’m the other matt but when I’m doing that technique I’m usually just working on a single cycle of the waveform. It’s tedious, but to me it’s totally transparent, and I’m rarely cross fading because it just doesn’t need it at that microscopic level. But I have no doubt that the better matt is right about it on bigger sections. 

When I do it in protools (the slightly larger sections) I’ve found you can nudge one of the two things you’re cross fading sample by sample and you’ll watch the over lapping waveforms kind of level out at a specific spot where it’s the most transparent sounding fade. 

A majority of time I find if you’ve cut up your blobs properly in melodyne, melodyne works just fine, but on the really really delicate shit I’ll do the single cycle wave form duplication. 

(I hope this makes sense, I’m hurtling through the air at 35000 feet on a not insignificant amount of Xanax)

author: Jack
content:
My immediate spitballed thoughts are: 

— Percussion can be less invasive than harmonic additions (but also sometimes way more invasive) 

— Doubling vocal/other melodies with different instrumentation in unison rather than something contrapuntal  

— Additions that live harmonically below the vocal melody tend to be less attention grabbing, lowpass also tends to psychologically push them back 

— There’s a clip where @oaklandmatt mentioned recording his Juno’s noise separately to mix in at will which opened my eyes to how bizarrely ‘functional’ just ambience can be. Sometimes mixing in some field recording can work wonders. 

— Processing verb/delay sends can bring some more prominence to what’s already there

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content:
Some ideas:

- cut out lots of stuff for a bar or less before chorus
- stereo field narrow -> wide 
- frequency balance more mid centric -> full spectrum
- less subdivisions -> more subdivisions
- less legato instruments filling dead space -> more
- lower actual level -> higher (like @Bryan DiMaio said, cleverly and smartly)
- Some kind of "hit"/stab/cymbal starting chorus
- Tempo automation sometimes, slower or faster into chorus can work

All that said, my fav is when the vocal/melody automatically lifts the energy and the rest derives from that

author: chris_donlin

author: Zakhiggins
content:
Im pretty much always messing with the length of kick, snare and hat trying to get them to fit in the grove better, you can make some unlikely pairs work when you do this.

Also always messing with the order in which transients are hitting on downbeats, nudging certain drums slightly before or after others can make things mesh together real nice. Typically the higher pitched/attacky things like hi hats come earlier than the sub kicks for example but experiment with it and see what sounds good. A song where this is really obvious is say it right by nelly furtado, listen to the way the layers are stacked on the downbeats of the chorus. Side note, when you're doing this, think of everything with a transient on that downbeat as a percussion instrument.

author: wilhelmjosephk
content: I love this sound and a lot of the other stuff that Jockstrap's come up with, and while this is a bit of a non-answer, I think the key is that these sounds are easier to arrive at than they are to aim for. I think a lot of what Taylor Skye is doing is taking sounds and then warping them/distorting them to shit using all of the "wrong" methods, and then just judging what comes out and deciding if it should be kept. I think there's a good hint of this in the lead sound at the start, where it's really out of rhythm and grainy, some notes seem to sort of "break" which reminds me of the results you get when you try to formant shift a verbed-out or polyphonic sound with little alterboy, or even abusing izotope RX on something that doesn't really need it (also, the RX de-reverb can do wild things to a sound you've put reverb on higher in the chain). Logic, which is what he uses, also has a lesser known formant shift that you can only get to by turning on flex pitch then adjusting in the side info bar, which can really take sounds into space. I haven't done this with melodyne, but I imagine there are some similar features.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yup! Massive was my go-to for years prior to Massive X.

The biggest change for me is that the raw oscillators sound far better. The original Massive had a lot of aliasing that could make it sound hazy and flat. Switching over to Massive X it is crystal clear and even buzzy saw waves feel warm, pure, and tactile.

It has extremely flexible modulation capabilities that I find to be very musical as well as some very comprehensive ADSHR envelopes. It also has four different keyboard tracking curves that you can assign and tweak, which is very important when fine-tuning your patch to make sure that it sounds even across the entire range of keys.

It has a lot of musical sounding filters that can inject a ton of vibe, or be completely neutral. The *noise* section is robust and very flexible. I use it a lot.

Finally, it has a great-sounding set of internal effects (delay, chorus, saturation, verb, etc) that can be placed anywhere inside of the routing diagram. It's always a bummer when the on-board effects aren't very inspiring. But NI has a strong catalog of well-designed dsp to draw on and integrate into their products, so it's turned out great.

Overall, it's a very robust and well-rounded synthesizer that also does a lot of things extremely well. It can be super clean (like Serum) but also get very dirty, which I appreciate in a synth.

The only thing I don't like is that the preset browser kind of sucks. I prefer the original Massive's browser. NI is well aware and they have been overhauling it and slowly adding new features, so I trust in time this will be made better.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I don't know that music being hard is necessarily a good thing for it's own sake. I'd rather have it be easy and lower the friction between conception and realization. A lot of tech these days enables that ease and has opened the door to more people writing and producing their records.

But a secondary side-effect that I think we can all observe - and I think this is more to your point - is that musicians are leaning into those methods and not pursuing the hard work and practice that is necessary to do things like singing well, or playing piano with more than a base level of proficiency, or orchestrating an ensemble well. The expressive unlock of being highly proficient isn't being pursued like it was in the past decades (before we had so may technological means). People are - broadly speaking - more satisfied these days to settle for records that don't push into that potential.

What we lose are the heights of expression that virtuosity unlocks. Whether that's singing like Aretha Franklin, or playing a simple ballad like Bill Evans, or writing a song with as much sophistication and lyrical wit as Joni Mitchell.

author: Slow Hand

Hmmm. I don't have any super-fresh tools to recommend, but a few come to mind:

Polyverse make some very interesting stuff, like *Manipulator* and *I Wish*. Very musical tools. Real time, too!

*PaulXStretch* is still great for super-long FFT stretches. They made an AU, VST, AAX plugin version a few years ago that's solid.

It may be worth focusing on producing first. You’ll get quicker wins without relying on your own sound design, and using high-quality Serum presets gives you material to reverse engineer.

author: Will Trotman
content:
In addition to the diamonds like Noah said, just root notes chugging away or playing 8th notes can be helpful and non invasive if chords or power chords feel too informative. Octaves can be a cool halfway point. A lot of songs seem to have room for the clean “dinky” sort of electric parts (sometimes slightly melodic or sometimes just hanging out on a single note).

If it’s a matter of filling space, something that helped me on a pop track the other day was making a second track for echoes of the lead vocal where you can low pass it pretty hard and delay / verb it out.

I often find myself introducing subtle sub basses later in the song, potentially doubling electric bass with synth bass, maybe layering snares to be fatter in later choruses. Then playing with some subtle percussion elements like triangle, clave, wood blocks, to differentiate later choruses.

I composed/recorded a boy band track for an ad…it was only :30 so it was easy to do this, but we got everyone singing the lead lines as If they were the “lead singer” and we comped which singer we wanted for each line after. Then we had them do harmonies for all the lines as well (at least the lines we knew we wanted harmonies) 

They were great enough singers they just did a bunch of harmony takes and it was super fast and easy to layer and edit. If the singers are good it’s honestly its super easy. 

Since it’s an actual group and not an ad, you might have to pre produce some of these concepts, who wants what “verses” as their lead section etc.

author: Slow Hand
content:
If you're concerned about being too suggestive to the players about their parts then strip back the demo until it contains only the most essential parts. No fancy stuff. Just chords, melody, and lyric. *Maybe* a kick drum pattern. Lead sheet style.

If the song is good then it will still be compelling. The best songs tend to be very robust and can be played a dozen different ways because they are fundamentally compelling. If the demo doesn't feel good this way then the song may need more work.

Lesser songs will depend on the arrangement or production to be compelling, or only work in a narrow band of styles. Sometimes a song can only work one way. It's okay if this is the case for your song, but then it's up to you to present the demo with the arrangement or elements that are essential to make the song compelling, and that will close off more and more of the instrumental possibilities.

So if you want to increase the chances of a session player delivering an unexpected, brilliant, idea then set them up for success with a strong song that can be interpreted many ways.

----

author: austenballard
content:
I didn't doubt you were right,  I wanted to measure it to see it for myself and record the process and results for anyone else who might be curious.

I'm also glad I tested it because not only is tuning different between the different versions, like you said, but detection is different as well! And this is not disclosed at all by Celemony in the Melodyne documentation, unless you infer it from that bit in the manual I screenshotted yesterday.

I think in general it's important to rigorously test our tools when we suspect or observe that they're not working as they should. The likes of GS and Vi-Control are full of people talking about issues but never actually testing them. We can do better here, especially when testing, like you did with Auto-Tune, leads to an opportunity to put queries and complaints to the manufacturers themselves.

Most synths come with manual page with SysEx (system exclusive). If you want to use hands, it will automatically pick up the parameter automation and record into the daw as long as you have hooked up midi in and midi out. Some synths can just do this with usb.

author: Deleted User
content:
inner harmonies are more textural than functional, they exist to fill the space in the middle, but they can also take up too much space. key players and guitarists are guilty of this too often. no need for a 7 note voicing in a dense pop song

But chord “progressions” are also underrated in a sense that it really shifts the emotional context. you can really make a pretty significant difference by carefully crafting them, but also that doesn’t mean you need all the stuff in between bass and the main melody on every songs

instruments like chord stabs can serve the function of percussion and drive the rhythm. it’s ‘rhythm sectio’  afterall

author: gatewoodsensei
content:
I’m not sure if this’ll help, but I tend to go with whatever hits me at the time. If it’s a melody, I’ll sing it, mumble words, and allow the music to form around that idea. If it’s lyrics, then i grab a guitar or sit in front of the keyboard and play the accompaniment. Or if I’m in front of my computer, and melody line hits, I’ll play the melody, or chords and allow it to loop while I write. So I don’t necessarily balance, because to me that means I’m shutting part of my creativity off i order to allow the other part to flow, and more often than not, that kills the creative flow. 

So don’t try to balance anything. Whatever you feel, go with that and allow your creativity to flow.

You’ve got your drums …..and built your vocal chops , the chops are like your keys part …..and then you’re gonna weave a stealthy , hooky baseline to syncopate and spin with your chops and drums . Definitely keep the lead separate.

author: LAPhill
content:
Years ago, I had to create a soundalike of a Miley Cyrus song, starting with the tempo. I discovered that it had a carefully constructed rise of 1bpm every 4 or 8 bars, for the first intro/verse/prechorus, until landing something like 6bpm by the first chorus. It was one of those "aha!" moments for me.

Just because you're recording to a click doesn't mean you can't build in some of a musician's natural tendencies to speed up and slow down. It's only a limitation if you let it be. (But I will echo @SoundsLikeJoe and @Ross Fortune , sometimes the only way is without a click. Whatever serves the song best)

author: Slow Hand
content:
Sounds like a vibe! I would embrace the tempo shifts. To map out the tempo in your DAW I would do the following steps:

1. Identify the steady starting tempo at the beginning of each section (intro, verse, chorus) and get them aligned to a steady tempo as best you can.

2.  Then start working out the tempo ramps between each section (start of Verse 1 to the start of Chorus 1) and keep an eye on how well the waveform is aligning with the grid as you adjust the tempo automation. You may have to curve the automation gently to match the shape of their automation ramp.

3. RInse and repeat for each additional section until you have a completed tempo map for the entire song.

author: Maxim
content:
Sounds like you’re looking for density without it being cluttered or overproduced. 

Usually “noise” (not literally but parts of the groove that you mainly feel but don’t make out specifically like you would a kick and snare or hi hat) serves this purpose for me. Elements which if muted would leave you feeling like something is missing but you can’t necessarily make them out when in. 

I guess this could be anything from a few percussion loops (maybe panned/verb with no pre-delay or less high end to place them at the back of the mix) to a subtle vocal or foley sample playing one note throughout the groove. 

Layering to me is part of this but my intent with it is usually to create a sound or get more out of an element (like layering the attack of a snap with a clap for a different transient / texture). But this doesn’t always add to “fullness” in my mind. It just makes one element better or more interesting. 

Maybe start with the loops and foley. Splice Bridge makes testing things really easy too.

author: Adam Thein
content: In Ableton Live I’ll usually do whatever I need to do with Melodyne then immediately flatten it back to audio so I can do things like clip gain or timing.  The more I’ve used Melodyne the less I like the workflow of transferring into the plugin. author: Ross Fortune

Not Melodyne, but AutoTune graphic mode allows you to edit audio on the timeline after it’s been transferred into the plug. Handy if you spot a click or a mouth noise you missed.

author: ehutton21
content:
Vocalign is really essential to my work flow because of how many harmonies i get from clients & collaborators. I also create doubles with it a lot & use melodyne/alterboy to enhance the texture. 

As far as editing groove/timing, that’s hard cause I always cut that stuff until it feels right. Most of the time I’m gettin tracks where the artist or the producer or whoever (lots of times it’s the same person) has already agonized over the timing and cut it up so it’s solid. I’m mindful of words where the first syllable is cacophony or plosive-based (k, t, d) when it comes to sounds that hit on the quarter note (esp with snares). I usually let those sounds start just before the transient and end so that vowel is starting right on the note, depending on how it’s quantized if that makes sense. 

Feel like groove editing gets a weird wrap but i here songs where the timing could have used aligning after the amount of compression that got applied.

author: Slow Hand
content:
(Ok. Now I'm starting to run with this train of thought. Now would be a good time to step off if you've gotten what you need.)

I don't want this to sound like the end-all be-all. One of my absolute favorites is James Brown, and there is no way that some of his songs would hold up to the level of scrutiny I'm describing. And those records *kill*. It's all vibe. It's vibe all the way down, bebe. Not a chord change in sight. Barely a melody in some cases. And that's alright.

So what did James do? More often than not James would get all of his band (real jazz killers) in the studio and he would sing the parts to them one by one and allow them to input their own feel.

He'd start with the drummer and have them play a pattern that James was feeling. Once the drummer was jamming on that he would move on to the bass player and sing them an idea. Once the bass player had that germ of an idea they would continue to jam on it with the drummer, refining and adding their own thing. Then James would move on to the horns, and so on, and so on.

While James could be dictatorial and (from the perspective of music education) the least technically qualified person in the room he had *vision*. 

If the song has a strong identity you can give your players a good (non-technical) prompt and they can interpret that through their own sensibilities. You can describe a mood, or a scene, or an abstract sensation.

R. Kelly once said (I'm paraphrasing): "RnB is supposed to feel like the best moment of your *life*." That simple description conveys so much about the feel, the pleasure, and the joy that he is looking for in his music. It also excludes a lot of possibilities as well. If you can give your players a prompt like *that* then you can get everyone aligned on the same wavelength and it will carry you so much further without the need to dictate parts.

----

author: austenballard
content:
So I was digging through the Discord for wisdom on comping/tidying/timing/tuning vocals and seems like there's some debate on whether one should time first or tune first. 

I like to time first, because:

- AFAIK time-stretching tends to emphasize tuning artifacts, while tuning can actually mask timing artifacts depending on how drastic the timing was.

- I'm often comping doubles from unused lead takes, and then doing a combination of Revoice and editing by hand to line them up, along with harmonies. I find this makes tuning easier, especially when to lining up a slide or melisma.

HOWEVER

- I could be mistaken/misinformed about the first point. I think the amount of artifacts also depends heavily on what DAW/algorithm was used for time-stretching, if it was done at all.

- Tuning can mess with timing. We all saw the AT conversation a few days ago, and Matt Beckley pointed out in a post a while back that Melodyne can also make timing a little wonky sometimes.

OTHER CONSIDERATIONS

- Is this just one of those 'it depends' situations?

- You can do both timing and tuning in Melodyne, although (to me) it feels a little more artifacty and a lot more time-consuming than working by hand and applying stretching, etc. as needed.

@BatMeckley @NoahNeedleman I feel like you two probably have the most expertise here - advice greatly appreciated.

author: JakeTB
content:
Method: Recorded vocal at 192kHz into Pro Tools. Exported via Shift+CMD+K at 192kHz and again at 48kHz. Vocals were both imported into Melodyne application in monophonic mode. Administered time stretching (both lengthened and shortened) via the time tool. Also administered pitch shifting via pitch tool and checked detection of tuning via correct pitch macro. After exporting these, they were reimported to see if detection had changed.

Objective Results:
-Upon import, vocal tempo detection was different. (One detected in 5/4, the other in 3/4, at drastically different tempos).
-For short notes, when using the time tool to stretch, there were audible differences in results.
-For long notes, when using the time tool to shorten, there was significantly less audible difference (subjectively: no difference)
-For pitch detection, the algorithm detected pitch differently both audibly and visually.

Subjective Opinions:
-Time stretching yielded reduced artifacts in extreme settings when done at 192kHz. It did not eliminate all artifacts, but did reduce them.
-When time stretching in a more nuanced way, the differences in artifacts were negligible.
-When adjusting pitch manually, there was no audible difference in the quality of the pitch shifting at different sample rates. (For this test, everything was shifted up half an octave before any adjustments made)
-When detecting pitch, both behaved quite differently. This was partially due to detection of select blobs being different at either sample rate. (This was most surprising to me of all the results)
-When blobs were adjusted to match as closely as possible by hand, the tuning seemed to behave identically, including locations and levels of artifacts. (My gut says they “felt” different but that is most likely either placebo or the slight differences in true blob locations)

author: Deleted User
content:
Reverb throw might be a better choice than a revealing crossfade. Especially it being a very emotionally charged part. I've spent about 4 hours on this outro trying to figure out how to move the fades around to make it work but this one particular phrase was not coming together and there weren't other usable takes either. 

What I've done so far is I added a little decresc and cresc that wasn't there before, which made it more natural and was still musically appropriate. And did some audio suite EQ moves to match the formant as best as I can between the two takes. and then messed around with clip gain automation and fade points and shapes to see if I can get them to connect seamlessly. 

I could probably do it better next year, but this needs to be done now - so I think I'm just gonna go ahead and put on a reverb throw haha:kekcry:

author: peterlabberton
content: I had this happen once with a really rad band I worked with—we hashed out a bunch of parts/arrangement/etc., and then they re-did everything mostly note for note to get out of a deal, in order to own their master. Kinda can't blame 'em for wanting the master, but wish I'd been credited. Seemed at the time and now like there's no recourse.

author: austenballard
content:
I have been on both sides of this situation

One example was that the producer had ghosted the artist, so I redid the instrumental note for note, matching synth patches and everything. Artist decided not to credit the original producer. He got mad and threatened to sue but the legal fees would probably be more than any royalties he made, so that all fizzled out

Another example was that the artist found someone who could finish the project plus mix and master it for less than they would have had to pay me for the final arrangement deliverables. At least I got my 50% down payment.

author: BatMeckley
content:
But you can’t control their behavior, just yours. I feel like we’re moving the goal posts here a bit… i know some pretty verifiably shitty human beings that are massively successful songwriters, and people look the other way because they consistently deliver. 

My Dad used to have this concept he called “would you throw your dog off a roof”… people would always ask him in the lean years “why do you play these shitty state fairs all the time” and he would respond with that analogy… “would I throw my dog off the roof for $100? NO. Not for anything. He’s family. I love him.” Would you throw your dog off the roof for $100 million dollars? “Well he pisses on the carpet and he’s always barking at the mailman and…”

That example of where Metallica doesn’t work with Bob Rock anymore neglects to take into account that they’re in the very rare air where it doesn’t really matter how well the records do anymore, and having said that the foundation that BR helped build ensured a fan base that will make sure any new record won’t totally tank regardless. So it doesn’t really apply to your situation.

author: LAPhill
content: To further dig in on the pre delay time - It also affects the perception of how far into the room the source is. If you have a long predelay, it creates the effect that your source is close to you, in a large space. Conversely, no prelay will position your source farther into the room, where the reverb and direct signal hit your ear concurrently. (These effects work in tandem with wet/dry mix to further accentuate the positioning)

author: Deleted User
content:
But I do want to clarify about my one take musician thing… 

I may have used the term too loosely. To me, most jazz musicians are one take players. They record everything together and calls it. (of course they do a few takes but I’m not trying to be a “first take and that’s it” player)

Being able to play through the whole song (unless arrangement calls for section by section) and just needing to punch in a few spots is what I want. I do not have any desires to go beyond that. 

BUT

I don’t ever want to edit my timing other than micro adjustments that can be done by moving small part of audio clip or hitting quantize. 

That + being more consistent with touch so I don’t have to punch in as much

2. Vocal chops

Think of your vocal chops as a keys part . Play the chops backwards , re form a new melody , reverse etc . These chops are now a rythmic device

author: Deleted User
content:
Art is subjective, so there’s actually no “better” — This is something I need to remind myself of more. The amount of times that I showed something that I thought was good and was rejected, and the times I showed something I hated and got good reactions from  people. You really never know! 

I’ve been doing more writing sessions these days (once or twice a week or so), and I’m really falling in love with this because I can get out of my own head and look around to get a sense of whether an idea is working or not outside of my own opinions

Speaking of the relentless will to finish: would it be a producer’s job to stay on top of getting others in team to get their parts done? If I’ve done my part already and completed it, do I keep bothering them to get their parts done? (lyrics etc) 

I read your reply to someone asking about writing sessions, and you said your biggest goal is to get the vocals from the first spark of inspiration on that same day. I’ve had sessions where I get a basic bone of ideas with beat done, and top line is done but the lyrics are recorded in Gibberish and stream of consciousness. I would return, complete the arrangement on my own - send it back, they said they fuck with it and tells me they will finish the lyrics. How long do I wait, do I follow up at all, or do I just move on and keep making more? I don’t want to overstep or rush people (and.. I can’t get anyone to anything of course), but I also want to get the song done while I’m excited so I can keep moving forward. It’s hard to tell if I can even do about it or if I should just keep it moving and leave it be

author: markmaclure

Anyone have any tips on working with new artists/producers with no filter? Like where they NEED to try out every idea they have, even if it's not good, or if it's a bad time (ie we're tracking guitars and they stop everyone to try out a (bad) bass idea). 

I'm on a project right now where a new artist is bringing their songwriting partner to every session as a producer. This is their first production gig (which is fine), but we're wasting a lot of time on ideas that get scrapped later on. This person has a good ear, and occasionally has GREAT ideas, but it takes forever for them to let go of bad ideas. 

It takes all of my patience to very slowly walk them through why the ideas aren't working, and there's a lot of pushback when I do. A lot of "but can we just try it? I really feel like it will work" then 3 hours later "oh yeah I think you were right let's delete it".

author: chris_donlin
content: Does anyone have a quick way to take a melodic riff on guitar/keys/etc and have each note play in reverse? I dont want the whole clip to just play backwards. I want the melody the same. Slice to new midi track in ableton almost gets me there but i cant reverse the samples within each sampler... or can i?

author: ! Andy !
content: Slice each note you want to reverse in the audio file & hit r

author: Slow Hand
content:
I don't think *slice to MIDI* is the way here. It will become tedious if you have rests in between notes.

Imagine that you have a quarter note followed by a quarter note rest in your melody. If you *slice to MIDI* it will slice that sequence into a half-note length clip. If you then reverse that clip the rest will play *first*, followed by the reversed quarter note.

author: Slow Hand
content: Doing it manually is probably the safest bet until someone writes a Max patch to automate it. Print to audio, slice at the note start and end, and then hit *R* to reverse the desired notes.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Other strategies for re-vamping the feel and arrangement:
1. Trying putting instruments in different registers (move the bass up/down an octave).
2. Play the song in a neutral form like only piano and vocals and listen for what it might suggest.
3. Substitute instruments (Ex: bowed bass instead of electric bass).
4. Try a different key.
5. Try half-time. Try double-time.

author: Deleted User
content:
I want to chime in here, I mostly agree with what the others said and as long as you don’t unintentionally clip all is well. But I think we can dig a bit deeper.

I like to work in a way during tracking/production that’s maybe a bit more old school with shooting for around -18dbFS on the average. It gives me a kind of fixed reference in my mind which gives me enough headroom for most dynamics. Now the important part is you have to turn up your monitoring/headphones volume to be adequately loud to work with those lower levels and then leave it there.That being said it might be necessary to bring down other pre existing tracks that are too loud.

Now since the volume of the monitoring/headphones stays the same during that tracking session you can use the gain of your preamp (or the output gain of the compressor, if you’re using one on the way in) to adjust the vocal or instrument so that for every part of the arrangement it feels right. So in a sense you are pre mixing during the recording, taking off some work down the line

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
My current approach to this involves a couple of principles, but this is the first that comes to mind:

1. If there’s a part with bg vocals performing different lines than the lead and there’s a lot going on, I try to have a spot earlier in the song where the exactly lines those BGs are performing have a moment to shine. For example, if there’s a low energy bridge where they can be clearly understood before the big hook where they can be perceived but not understood as well in the midst of so much. 

What this does is allow the listeners brain to process what’s being said with little effort, and then later when it’s in a tornado they can still perceive what it’s saying because they recognize it as something their brain already knows, so it’s not overwhelming for their brain to understand the words of multiple vocals going at once if there are layers of lines being performed (usually syncopated) around each other.

This applies to instruments as well, but instead of intelligibility of words I focus more on cutting frequencies so everything can fit well in the big moments. If they head a synth at full power in the intro and it comes back for a final hook, you can get away with cutting a lot of meat off of it and still have it be perceived as the same synth, without muddying the mix and also creating a nice ‘bringing the song full circle’ feeling - If the track calls for that.

I typed this off the cuff based in gut instinct so not standing by this message as full proof, but this all feels right to me as I explore what I have done for tracks, without having this much thought or words to it.

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
To stick with a song I made, MIRROR, I had the lead say anxieties earlier in the song in the middle, then later add those full lines as BGs that almost swirl around the last hooks lead. The lead is performing a part that’s trying to overcome anxieties, and the BGs are saying full lines with the anxieties from before.

Panning was essential to create the effect of the anxieties around the lead, but I found that if I introduced them as panned BGs they were hard to make out behind the lead.

Because of this, knowing when to make a moment earlier in the song to spotlight what would later be panned made those lines more intelligible once they were in the BG to the sides, because the listeners brain recognized it from an earlier section.

Does that make sense? I can struggle to explain what I’m doing in practice and this is my attempt, so my bad if it sounds like gobrish

author: Slow Hand
content:
Oh I certainly feel that. 

I'll often find myself making records that start to fall into three or four different buckets (ex: heavy stuff, singer songwriter, experimental, etc...). I start grouping together the tracks that feel complimentary and then when I have enough they'll start to suggest a direction for an album, at which point I'll focus on that larger project until it's complete.

Then I jump back into the songs in the remaining buckets and use them as the jumping off point for the next release. That's one way to do it.

author: Slow Hand
content:
If you learn how diatonic chords work it can take you far. Every key has what are called it's diatonic chords. These are chords that are made from the notes in your major or minor scale.

**For example:** In the key of F, your diatonic chords are these:

F, Gm, Am, Bb, C, Dm, E dim.

You can play any of those chords and they'll fit right in. Those are your "can't lose" chords that will sound coherent no matter what. I would start here by chaining some of these chords together and seeing how they sound. They're like words in a sentence that you can rearrange to say different things.

author: BananErMat42
content:
Bit of a ramble here, guess its a little pushback to commonly seen advice on making music.

Last night i again went at a song ive been working on for an album. I’m three years in by this point and this song is the one that has been the most difficult. Ive made huge rearrangements and changes to this song probably 5-6 times by this point, and always came back to it thinking it still isnt there. The basic concept is alluring but my execution is lacking. 

So most people say "scrap it", if the song doesnt come easy then its not meant to be, and you’re better served making a new track entirely. Maybe integrate the best ideas, but start over. You’re in too deep and you’ll never hear it for what it is by this point.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I haven't been as hands-on with all the non-autotune options as some, but my impression is that if you are simply using the auto mode feature of auto tune to get the sound, you can get some comparable results with things like Waves Tune, the Logic and Ableton native versions, etc. I'm sure there are differences, but you can at least get close.

If you're doing graphical tuning, Melodyne and Auto-tune are the standards. Logic has flex pitch but reliable people I've talked to say it doesn't have nearly the transparency as the other two. I also don't know anyone who uses it over Auto-tune or Melodyne.

author: Beck Nebel

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Of course there are limits to this technique too. The further you nudge any single edit, the more audible it will become. So if you want to lengthen or shorten a note A LOT, sometimes you will have to do multiple edits, or longer cross fades, or something else to achieve the most transparent result.

And one of the best in the biz is @BatMeckley who I'm sure has thoughts about when to hand edit vs using Melodyne's time adjuster.

I use autotune graphic and never use the timing feature so I can't help you there

author: Slow Hand
content:
@Akanksha Co-sign on what Matt has said here. Learning to write chord progressions is a strong skill to develop. Chords are what gives your song harmonic motion and a sense of going places. They can give it tension and release. A good progression will show you where to take the song next.

Or you can write a melody first and then come up with chords underneath it. Whichever feels more natural to you. No wrong answers here.

author: spectrummasters
content:
One of the most helpful things to break out of the 4/8 bar loop of death is to begin your project with the audio file of a track you love the arrangement for imported . 

Mute it and set your project to its tempo (it’s just easier ) 

Now get to jamming away 

Once you’ve built the loop you adore , 
Mute it 

Listen again from top to bottom the track you love the arrangements for . 

Listen to how the different elements come in and out , where , how . 

How are the motifs evolved . Any counter melody / rythms .

Drops and breakdowns 

Make notes of it all . 
Then copy it exactly or to the degree you want with your own elements of your loop . 

Voila . You made a fully arranged track . 

Repeat

author: spectrummasters
content: Now you’re an arrangement don

author: austenballard
content:
I also really like to get hyper-organized inside the project folders so I make a folder for bounces, a folder for committed trackouts (which i prefer vs freeze/flatten, but do it however it works for you), and then folders for ancillary stuff like lead sheets, lyric sheets, etc

also make sure you each bounce after each version

also helps to freeze (but not flatten) in case your collaborator doesn't have the same plugins or presets or whatever so you can keep rolling back and forth even if you're using different plugins

author: austenballard
content:
plus also folders for any RX or Melodyne or Revoice, etc. you might do in the process

sorry for being a little discombobulated in my explanations but i hope my little braindump helps!
